title: Understanding the Reaction
text: To calculate the standard entropy change, ∆S°, for the reaction, you need to understand the relationship between Gibbs free energy, enthalpy, and entropy. The equation is: $$∆G\degree=∆H\degree-T∆S\degree$$.

title: Identify Known Values
text: Identify the values given in the problem: $$∆G\degree=-32.89$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, ∆H°f for $$C2H4=52.47$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, $$H2=0$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, and $$C2H6=-84.68$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$. Remember to convert ∆G° to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$ by multiplying by $$1000$$.

title: Calculate ∆H° for the Reaction
text: Use the standard heats of formation to calculate ∆H° for the reaction: $$∆H\degree=(∆H\degreef$$ of $$products)-(∆H\degreef$$ of reactants).

title: Rearrange the Gibbs Free Energy Equation
text: Rearrange the equation $$∆G\degree=∆H\degree-T∆S\degree$$ to solve for ∆S°: ∆S°=(∆H°-∆G°)/T.

title: Calculate ∆S°
text: Substitute the values of ∆H°, ∆G°, and T (298 K) into the rearranged equation to find ∆S°. Remember to keep units consistent.
